hedline.hl1: New York to Albany Faster, via France

abstract.p: First of seven high-speed trains being rebuilt by SuperSteel are to be in service between New York City and Albany by end of year, cutting trip by 30 minutes, to about 2 hours (S)

block.p: The rail trip between New York City and Albany will be cut by 30 minutes, to about two hours, as rebuilt high-speed French-designed turboliners are put into service and tracks and signals are upgraded to accommodate them.

The first of seven high-speed trains being rebuilt by SuperSteel of Schenectady, N.Y., is expected to be in service between New York City and Albany by the end of the year; an additional train is supposed to be put on line every four to six months thereafter. The diesel-powered trains can travel at up to 125 miles an hour.

The rail trip between New York City and Albany will be cut by 30 minutes, to about two hours, as rebuilt high-speed French-designed turboliners are put into service and tracks and signals are upgraded to accommodate them.

The first of seven high-speed trains being rebuilt by SuperSteel of Schenectady, N.Y., is expected to be in service between New York City and Albany by the end of the year; an additional train is supposed to be put on line every four to six months thereafter. The diesel-powered trains can travel at up to 125 miles an hour.

Each rebuilt train costs $10.8 million and is being paid for by Amtrak and the New York State Department of Transportation. The turbotrains, made up of two power cars, two coaches and a cafe car, were originally put into service in the mid-1970's.

Amtrak currently provides 13 daily round trips between New York City and Albany. The fare for service aboard a turboliner will remain the same, starting at $40 one way. Reservations: (800) 872-7245 or at www .amtrak.com.
